docs.title: RUNNING  DOCKER ON A MULTIPASS VM
PART 1
docs.text: This document a step-by-step guide for setting up and running Docker within a Multipass Virtual Machine VM.

docs.title: 2. Launch a Multipass instance
docs.text: write the following command in your Terminal to launch a new Ubuntu instance bash multipass launch --name docker-vm

docs.title: 3. Acces the Multipass instance
docs.text: Access the Multipass VM once it is running: bash multipass shell docker-vm

docs.title: 4. install docker
docs.text: Still in the Multipass shell install docker bash sudo apt update sudo apt install -y docker.io

docs.title: 5. Test Docker installation
docs.text: after installation test docker to verify if it is working with a simple command: bash docker run hello-world

docs.title: 6. Using Docker
docs.text: to pull an image : docker pull < name-image > to list the running containers: bash docker ps to run a container: bash docker run -d <image-name>

docs.title: 7. Stop a Multipass instance:
docs.text: To stop a multipass instance and remove when your are done use the commands: bash multipass stop docker-vm multipass delete docker-vm multipass purge

docs.title: PART 2 : Alias
docs.text: Aliases in your shell configuration file (like .zshrc) are shortcuts that allow you to execute longer commands with a simpler, more memorable keyword. in our case to easily run docker commands in mltipass we are going to use an alias. here are the simple steps:

docs.title: 2. Add Aliases
docs.text: scroll to the bottm of the file and add your desired alias. here is an example: bash alias docker= "multipass exec docker-vm -- docker" this means if you write (docker ps)in your host shell it executes (alias docker= "multipass exec docker-vm -- docker") command.

docs.title: 3. Save and Exit
docs.text: in nana save the changes by pressing CTRL + O, then hit Enter and exit with CTRL + X.

docs.title: 5. Test your Alias
docs.text: This setup allows you to experiment with Docker without affecting your host machine.
